newsitem.title: BULGARIA: BULGARIA READY FOR CASH REPAY OF POLISH GRAIN SWAP.
newsitem.headline: BULGARIA READY FOR CASH REPAY OF POLISH GRAIN SWAP.

text.p: Bulgaria's agriculture ministry said on Wednesday that Poland has reaffirmed its readiness that the Balkan country could return 100,000 tonnes of wheat due by November 30 in cash rather than grain.
Under the current terms of the contract, Bulgaria must return 100,000 tonnes of wheat to Poland between October 1 and November 30 in exchange for grain imported in March.
Bulgaria suffered acute grain shortages earlier this year following uncontrolled wheat exports two years ago and a bad harvest in 1996.

Deputy Agriculture Minister Bogdan Kenderov told Reuters that Polish officials have confirmed at a meeting earlier this week that Poland is ready to be repayed in cash as the heavy floods last month did not heavily affected its grain crop.

"Polish Commercial Councillor to Sofia Adam Marzec said at the meeting that Poland would be able to secure its grain balance despite heavy floods in July and Bulgaria might pay in cash for the grain," Kanderov said.

Kenderov said both sides had agreed that Bulgaria's farm ministry should prepare draft amendments to the initial contract and submit them within ten days to the Polish embassy in Sofia for further approval by the Polish government.
Also, under two commercial contracts agreed with Swiss firm Glencore in March and May, Bulgaria must return a further 131,750 tonnes by November 1 in exchange for 100,000 tonnes imported.
Despite its delayed harvest due to rainfalls, Bulgaria expects to secure its annual consumption of 1.6 million tonnes of bread wheat and 800,000 tonnes of feed wheat.
